poll_list.title: Should we initiate the shutdown of the SCD system through an executive vote on April 24th, 2020?

content.content: With the extreme market changes we have seen in the past week, we have decided now would be a good time to once again engage in discussion about shutting down Single Collateral Dai. During today’s call, @Primoz presented information on the state of SCD here Governance and Risk Meeting: Ep. 78 - YouTube. In summary of his findings it became apparent that peg instability and liquidity issues were beginning to hinder the efficiency of the protocol. Liquidations were no longer taking place in an ideal fashion due to cost inefficiencies. This poses a great risk to PETH holders and the overall stability of the protocol. With this new information in mind, it seems prudent to begin advanced discussions on this topic. Several months ago I began collecting signals on the direction community members would like to take in shutting down SCD. A summary of the first polls can be found here:     Summary/Discussion of Parameters for SCD Shutdown Governance       The results are in!  After weeks of discussion and voting, I have closed the final signal polls for SCD Shutdown. To recap, with the community currently trying to maintain 2 separate Dai credit systems, I thought it imperative to begin the process of collecting opinion on when we should shut down the legacy system. Especially since there seemed to be a lack of consensus on the issue. This led me to begin with a signal on “When should we trigger SCD Global Shutdown”.    With this first signal I a…     While the latest conversation about introducing a tax to incentivize/penalize CDP users can be found here:     Signal Request/Discussion: Should we implement a tax during SCD Shutdown to recuperate unpaid Stability Fees? Signal Archive       Based on ongoing discussions on implementing the shutdown of our legacy Dai Credit System (SCD), the latest is in regards to how we may extract the remaining stability fees from CDP holdouts. If you are unfamiliar with this topic of discussion I encourage you to read/watch the following resources:                [Governance and Risk Meeting: Ep. 70]      With these resources you should start to see the picture that is emerging on the decisions that need to be made in regards to SCD Shutdown.  Wi…     Since both of these threads are now a little out of date I think it best if we reset some of the conversations given the new market conditions we live in. My goal in this thread will be to foster purposeful and meaningful discussion, and signalling, that moves us towards the end goal of SCD Shutdown. I encourage all community members to bring their ideas to the table in regards to how they would like to see this process play out and what they think are mitigating factors. Once some discussion has commenced we can begin to collect signalling on next steps. Some questions to begin discussion:  When should we enact ES? What parameters should we follow to trigger ES? Should we implement a tax on CDPs to recoup SCD fees? (see Signal Request/Discussion: Should we implement a tax during SCD Shutdown to recuperate unpaid Stability Fees?) Should we forgive SCD Fees? How do we find someone to clear out the migration contract before ES?  March 18th Edit Now that some discussion has taken place, I would like to begin with a few basic polls. When should we initiate SCD Shutdown?     Less than 1 week from today Less than 1 month from today More than 1 month from today     0 voters     Pros and Cons of initiating shutdown sooner rather than later Pros  Shutdown while price/liquidity are stable Less governance/risk overhead in the coming days/weeks/months CDPs may migrate to MCD and provide more Dai liquidity  Cons  Not enough time to communicate to CDP users No more MKR fees burned Opens up more ETH onto the market, could cause downward pressure on ETH price Could be bad optically. CDPs that paid fees and migrated to MCD could feel short changed. CDPs that weren’t prepared to settle right now could be effected financially.  If you have more pros/cons let me know and I’ll add them to the list. Should we forgive stability fees or try and extract fees in another way?     Forgive Extract     0 voters     Thoughts on forgiving stability fees versus extracting fees Technically we could calculate how much each remaining CDP owes in ETH and vote to manually extract that amount from each CDP. This however could look bad optically and would be time consuming for the Foundation. On the other hand, if we were looking to close later than the next few weeks we could signal to the community that a tax was being placed on remaining CDPs who did not choose to migrate and hopefully incentivize them to migrate willingly. All of the options to extract fees in order to incentivize CDP users to make a certain decision are much more time consuming than just forgiving the fees. Unless there is a more elegant solution that has not been brought forth yet. Forgiving stability fees is the fastest and easiest option. Optics are mixed because remaining CDPs would be happy but I would assume most ecosystem users are using MCD now and may feel slighted at having to pay fees unlike remaining CDP users. The obvious negative to this option is losing out on additional fees in the form of MKR burn which would have helped offset our Black Thursday losses. Additional Thought @Cyrus has brought up the point that before we initiate ES, we may need to find a willing party to absorb the migration contract. The reason this is necessary is because the migration contract is technically unbacked Dai and if there is Dai remaining in the contract at ES, it gets liquidated and at 4M Dai currently, there would be a lot of slippage. So in order to safely cancel out this contract, a helpful whale would need to mint Dai, migrate their Dai to Sai for the amount in the migration contract and then become settled in SCD. March 26th Edit Thank you to everyone for their input so far. Please go check out @Derek’s post about processes and next steps for SCD shutdown over here:     Sequential Process for SCD Shutdown Governance       Hi all, this post explains the sequential process for shutting down Single Collateral Dai. The process involves two executive spells; one to protect MCD and the other to shutdown SCD. I will outline what these steps are and why they are important. As of April the 19th you will notice that the section in (B) Executive Spell 2, now includes updated steps, a timeline and request Governance Vote support.  A) Executive Spell 1 - Set the SAI Debt Ceiling to 0 in MCD   This action will protect MCD by p…     Now that the previous polls have concluded, we can move on to the final forum poll stage. With “Less than 1 month from today” winning by 64%, we can now narrow our options down to a week in April. With the winner of the following poll chosen to go on chain for MKR holders to ultimately decide. Therefore: When should we initiate SCD Shutdown?     Friday, April 10th, 2020 Friday, April 17th, 2020 Friday, April 24th, 2020 Later Other     0 voters     My plan is to leave this open until Sunday evening/Monday morning so as to move on chain for Monday’s governance polls. If we haven’t received enough votes by then I will keep it open longer. Please remember this is just a signal and non-binding. As we know, things move fast in this space and changes may be necessary. I look forward to seeing the results. A note on fee forgiveness and clarity Since the voting was close on the forgive/extract poll, I just wanted to quickly discuss these implications. When inevitably put on-chain, the governance poll may be struck down for a myriad of reasons (shutdown too soon, would rather extract fees, etc.). Therefore it may be necessary to revisit the results of these polls and put together a different package to entice MKR voters. MKR holders ultimately have the final say and that is to be respected, regardless of outcome. It may even be necessary to redo the extract/forgive poll on-chain for full clarity as well as any other factors that may be uncertain. Ultimately, I hope that these forum polls have helped guide us in the right direction to passing what the majority of community members voted for.

content.content: Bit of a summary of chat discussion on this today. Some facts.  SCD debt outstanding is about 15M CDP 3088 is > 8M of this. I will add a link but it is looking like SCD auctions are not completing with DAI PEG around 1.03 SCD doesn’t have a GSM so if governance needs to change anything on the SCD we can do it quickly. LFW comments that perhaps we should shut down the SCD now before we experience another collateral price drop. Pros:  Doing it now we should have a decent SAI PEG so people can move. Gets MKR off the hook for any liabilities. liquidations in auctions - none are below 100% Also this ETH freed might find its way into MCD to provide more DAI Likelihood of more DAI coming into system Can formally close down the SAI-DAI bridge. Better to ES this now than to wait for a market collateral price drop.  Cons.  ETH will be freed to come on market to sell. SAI will basically be an option on ETH - SAI holders may end up selling causing a ETH/USD price event.  Issues.  Do we apply a fee.   Honestly at this point since it goes to PETH this seems moot.  Maker gets nothing out of shutting down SCD. PR - do we telegraph this or just shut it down.   Personally I think at least a PR post giving holders a warning that Maker is seriously considering shutting down SCD for the sake of giving everyone a chance to finally clear out of this system and for Maker to focus efforts on MCD management in these difficult times. Any development or ‘post ES’ UI work may need to be done.  We don’t want people upset they can’t get at their collateral or convert SAI to ETH in the system. If we don’t shutdown this system we just heap more issues on to MKR holders.  Based on the discussion general consensus of the small number of people participating is that it might be prudent to finally put a time frame on SCD shutdown.   Given state of the markets probably better to have this happen quicker.   So time for discussion is now. Total Maker could be on hook for given auctions/liquidation process is stuck is 15M-collateral value which will be heaped on SAI holders in the case of collateral price drop.   Right now it would be more likely for SAI to hold a $1PEG for people to clear this. Remember everyone has been warned multiple times the SCD/SAI system could shutdown at any time.

content.content: Recapping comments from the previous Governance call regarding how to absorb the migration contract; It is expected that Maker Governance will vote in an executive spell (time=tbd) to cage the system - meaning that it will no longer be possible to mint Sai. This caging activity will also shut down the facility to migrate Sai to Dai, however it will still allow Dai from MCD to be transferred to SCD. We refer to this as a ‘one-way bridge’. This bridge, coupled with the fact that we have just added USDC to the MCD protocol, puts us in a unique position to allow USDC collateral holders to mint DAI, and exchange this Dai for Sai, thereby draining the Sai migration contract by burning Sai for ETH and returning it back to MCD as Dai used to pay down the original USDC position. The what (and how) in bullets  Prevent swapping Sai to Dai (by caging the SAI join adapter) Continue to allow swapping Dai to Sai (by allowing exit on the adapter to continue working) Call global settlement (call cage on the top.sol contract) Mint Dai through USDC Swap Dai for Sai Burn Sai for ETH Return ETH to MCD Exchange for Dai and pay off USDC  The tax/SF dynamic remains an outstanding question that still needs to be discussed based on the outstanding CDPs, as well as the warning duration as a result of the above polls.

For long term SAI/DAI holder “reasonable time” may be days.    The promise.   I have been wondering where all the Maker ‘promises’ are in documents because I am kind of wanting to see them to understand what has been promised to the greater community by Maker (whether this is Foundation or DAO governance).  Stable coins often have ‘redemption’ points where the redemption value is guaranteed to be $1 by some centralized entity.  There is no such guarantee within the Maker system.   Hence while the ‘goal’ of the community is to have the PEG return to $1 after ‘some’ time it is NOT guaranteed.     ethernian:   ES is not just “system shutdown”, ES is “Emergency Shutdown”. The emergency is not given now. Thus the shutdown needs broad discussion and really good justification and public risk analysis. Both are missing currently, IMHO.    I have argued the whole ‘emergency’ part of the shutdown mechanics is relevant only to circumstance.  For all intensive purposes the ES machinery IS the only shutdown machinery the circumstances determine if it was an Emergency, a malicious act, or Governance shutdown.  In either case the SAME machinery and effectively the same result occurs.  Now in the case of governance a spell could be cast to trigger the ES and have other things happen either before or after this trigger so in some sense the actual shutdown mechanics are different from Malicious Actor, or in response to an Emergency. As to shutdown being a broad discussion.   Maker already has work going on which will lead to a discussion of ‘conditions’ for when to use the ES as well as what happens from a risk scenario analysis during an ES.   Yes these and a whole bunch or other things are missing generally. On that we agree.     ethernian:  If MakerDAO makes the broader public think, it shutdowns the SAI not because of emergency but just for own profit, it will destroy the trust.  The worse, the more money people will lose because of forced SAI->ETH conversion.   The whole first sentence is simply speculative.  Maker community has been pretty clear since release of MCD that the SCD would be shutdown.   I have been one of the few voices suggesting to keep it open but to simply reduce the DC and increase the SF to urge people out of it - while providing sufficient SAI liquidity or mechanics for people to close.  Literally if Maker waits for more people to close we make more DAI doing that than closing it now.   As to forced SAI-ETH conversion - NOONE is forcing SAI holders to keep their SAI.   I know for a fact there are a lot of people holding SAI just so they can get a ETH conversion option.   If anyone is holding SAI now that isn’t paying down a CDP and the fact that SAI price is significantly > 1 is gambling, speculating, or uninformed.  To believe the system will just be kept open indefinitely AND for Maker to keep its promises for all eternity is just wishing and believing vs. scientifically observing the facts.     ethernian:  ES without emergency breaks both promises of stability and decentralization at the same time. The MakerDAO fork (clone) with fixed governance will come as the answer. Remember the chain of incentives lead to TheDAO coin split, and you will see similarities.   Anyone who ever thought Maker governance was ‘decentralized’ only had to look at the holders of MKR and governance voting.   While the GOAL is decentralization - governance is centralized to MKR whales.   At ANY time anyone can fork Maker SCD or MCD but unless they actually change how governance works they will still have the same system.  I don’t see that ETC actually did anything better than ETH.  Literally the fork was strictly political and based on financial interests plain and simple.   Right now while anyone can fork the protocol and I don’t see how such an event will help current SAI/DAI holders.   Who exactly are the folks that are magically going to come together to then provide the financial backstop to the new protocol?   What guarantees are they going to give and how would anyone know whether they could trust these new players any more than Maker. With the above in mind I agree with you on a number of counts.  MakerDAO needs to communicate better. a) About promises regarding any financial backstop with MKR governance/financial tokens, and promises period as well as the responsibilies of DAI holders, vault owners, governance, MKR holder, etc. b) About conditions for shutdown.  Given what i have seen what we really want is to minimize the cases where any shutdown is considered.  This is one of my personal goals with this protocol - but I am but a single small actor and I don’t think this surface will ever close to 0 area. Improve the protocol to stabilize and secure it against bad actors with significant financial resources and time. Alter the protocol so that its functions are more robust and rather than drive the market reflect the market. Make this system sustainable - that fees pay for system operations, build a reasonable surplus for emergencies, provide for creation of backing capital pools to insure against risk events and create additoinal liquidity creation and removal mechanisms.  It is my hope that more people rather than harping about how the system has failed them, or how it should change, or whatever negative machinations they want to posit - roll up their sleeves and find a way to cooperatively help to change this system for the positive. My general goal - for Maker to be the first decentralied bank for the entire world - and we need all hands on deck not just complaining about failures - but helping to document them - change them - together. Is it a truism that a completely transparent organization will both have the best and worst results because, being completely transparent means every failure is open to public scrutiny and opinion far and wide, while sucesses undergo unceremonious and unthankful acceptance. These are tough times for the entire world, Maker is not excluded it is my hope we find constructive positive ways to move forward rather than descend into negative destructive ones. BTW:  I have earned not .01DAI for any of my contributions to Maker over the past 6 months.  I am not paid to be here.  So far I choose to be because I don’t see anyone even trying anything better.   The same is true to me of ETC vs. ETH.  I choose ETH over ETC simply because I see more real work going on within the Ethereum Community vs. the ETC one.   Are there issues with all of these protocols.  ABSOLUTELY.   But I see this as a work in progress inspired by a number of actors over a long time culimnating with S. Nakimoto releasing Bitcoin solving a pretty hard problem applying PoW to ‘trust’ regarding a public ledger (that individual did not create this in a vacuum - the entirety of Bitcoin).  I believe if that if we apply work to this system as well as time to derive ‘experience’ we - you - I - and everyone else in these systems might actually change the world yet again - hopefully in ways that make it better for all of us in the long run. I think we stray off the OT from the OP but I think it these concepts are important to discuss generally.
